description: From Middle French, Old French retenir, from Vulgar Latin *retinīre, from Latin retineō (“hold back”), from re- + teneō (“to hold”).

verbs.description: retain (third-person singular simple present retains, present participle retaining, simple past and past participle retained)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To keep in possession or use.
examples: A strange thing was that Bovary, while continually thinking of Emma, was forgetting her. He grew desperate as he felt this image fading from his memory in spite of all efforts to retain it. Yet every night he dreamt of her; it was always the same dream. He drew near her, but when he was about to clasp her she fell into decay in his arms.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To keep in one's pay or service.
examples: A Benedictine convent has now retained the most learned father of their order to write in its defence.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To employ by paying a retainer.
(transitive, education) To hold back (a pupil) instead of allowing them to advance to the next class or year.

examples: A somewhat languid relish, retaining to bitterness.
